results.title: What Becomes a Star Most? For Tom Cruise, It’s Control.
results.abstract: Sheer force of will is now part of his potent mix of athleticism and charisma. That combination goes a long way to explain why “Top Gun: Maverick” is a hit.

results.title: What Makes Taika Waititi Run and Run and Run?
results.abstract: The “Thor: Love and Thunder” director can’t say no — to starring in “Our Flag Means Death,” making a soccer movie, writing a “Star Wars” idea, adapting Roald Dahl. For starters.

multimedia.caption: If he stepped back and considered all of his projects, “I’d probably have a panic attack,” Taika Waititi said. “I know there’s too many things.”
multimedia.copyright: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times

results.title: Joe Turkel, the Spectral Bartender in ‘The Shining,’ Dies at 94
results.abstract: Also memorably seen in “Blade Runner,” he was a favorite among directors looking for someone who could bring zealous professionalism to even the smallest role.

multimedia.caption: Joe Turkel in Stanley Kubrick’s “The Shining” (1980). Mr. Turkel’s ominously stoic presence shifted the film into a darker register.

results.title: Ken Knowlton, a Father of Computer Art and Animation, Dies at 91
results.abstract: His work at Bell Labs in the 1960s laid the groundwork for today’s computer-generated imagery in film and on TV.

multimedia.caption: Ken Knowlton, left, and his Bell Labs colleague Leon Harmon. Behind them is the computer-generated artwork they created in the mid-1960s titled “Computer Nude (Studies in Perception I).”
